standfirst:
В эксклюзивном интервью Ислам Каримов-младший рассказывает, что боится за некогда мелькавшую повсюду вездесущую Гульнару Каримову, впавшую в немилость к своему отцу-диктатору.

  • Uzbekistan's feuding first family and the mystery of the president's missing daughter
headline: Распря в семье президента Узбекистана и загадка исчезновения его дочери

standfirst: Labor leader Bill Shorten has attacked the federal government's Direct Action climate policy, calling it a Soviet-style system that will cost Australia dearly, while failing to achieve its goals. Shorten attacked the prime minister's 'science sledging' and accused him of appealing directly to shock jocks and internet trolls.
headline: Bill Shorten attacks Soviet-style Direct Action on climate change – video

standfirst: It's clearly been a long day in the Senate for David Johnston. The defence minister drops off a couple of times to the soothing sounds of his West Australian colleague, Greens Senator Scott Ludlam, and his thoughts on keeping Infrastructure Australia transparent
headline: Scott Ludlam’s Senate talk sees defence minister nod off – video

standfirst: The treasurer has denied that Clive Palmer is his 'daddy' despite claims from Nine Network TV host Karl Stefanovic that this is why the government is struggling to pass some of its legislation. Hockey said that the Australian public was his 'daddy and mummy', shifting the blame for not passing legislation onto the Greens
headline: Clive Palmer not my daddy, Joe Hockey insists – video

standfirst: Authorities in region accused of increasing tensions with Uighur Muslim population by imposing restrictions during Ramadan
headline: Chinese police seize matchboxes in Xinjiang security crackdown

standfirst: The aftermath of a helicopter crash in Gwangju, south-west South Korea, on Thursday, in which the entire crew of five firefighters died. The helicopter was reportedly returning to base after assisting in the search for missing passengers of the April ferry disaster. The deaths bring the total number of fatalities of those involved in the search to seven. Two divers previously drowned while searching inside the ship
headline: South Korean firefighters' helicopter ablaze after crash – video

standfirst: Shadow assistant treasurer Andrew Leigh reckons Joe Hockey's plan to shed tax office jobs is a dud, given ATO data which suggest they make more in revenue than their sackings will save. Join him in front of the Guardian Australia whiteboard for a show and tell – it's 'Smokin' Joe' in the firing line as Leigh makes the case for the number-crunching civil servants
headline: Andrew Leigh explains why tax office job cuts will cost more than they save – whiteboard explainer video

standfirst: A nation waits to learn whether it will be ruled by reformist Joko Widodo or hardline ex-general Prabowo Subianto
headline: Indonesia: rivals both claim victory in presidential election

standfirst: Almost 150,000 people were evacuated from their homes in the Philippines on Wednesday after typhoon Rammasun swept through Manila. Rammasun is the strongest storm to hit the country this year, cutting a path across the main island of Luzon before passing south of the capital on Wednesday, toppling trees and power lines and causing widespread blackouts
headline: Typhoon Rammasun: Philippines suffers widespread destruction – video report

standfirst: Passenger ship due to be refloated off Giglio and then towed to Genoa, where the hulk will be broken up
headline: Salvage operation on Costa Concordia reaches final stage

standfirst: Officials say operation in Giglio has proceeded without a hitch in preparation for cruise liner being towed away
headline: Costa Concordia successfully refloated

standfirst: Full process expected to take several days
headline: Costa Concordia: first stage of refloatation process complete

standfirst: Angry Argentina fans battle with riot police after their team lost 1-0 to Germany in the World Cup final. Thousands gathered in the centre of Buenos Aires but after the match, rioting broke out. Fifteen police officers were hurt and about 30 people arrested in the violence. Argentina last won the World Cup in 1986
headline: Argentina fans clash with police after losing to Germany in World Cup final – video

standfirst: Afghan troops surround suicide squad who carried out bombardment from neighbouring buildings
headline: Kabul airport comes under rocket fire

standfirst: Intelligence official says 'safe havens' were set up for members of Taliban-linked Afghan network behind Tuesday's bazaar bombing
headline: Afghanistan accuses Pakistan of letting Haqqani militants escape crackdown

standfirst: Suicide attacker detonates car packed with explosives in crowded Urgun bazaar, in bloodiest attack on civilians for years
headline: Afghanistan car bomb leaves at least 89 civilians dead

standfirst: Incoming Liberal-National party senator for Queensland James McGrath has called for the abolition of the health and education departments and the sale of the ABC if perceived left-wing bias is not addressed. In his maiden speech, McGrath also called for the immediate sale of ABC youth radio station Triple J, an increase in the GST, and an end to compulsory student union membership
headline: Sell Triple J, abolish education and health departments, says new government senator McGrath – video

standfirst: Attorneys claim evidence shows John Middleton, 54, was in jail 40 miles away when Alfred Pinegar was murdered in 1995
headline: Missouri poised to execute sixth inmate in 2014 despite fresh doubts

standfirst: Colleen Simon filed a lawsuit alleging she was wrongfully fired from her job for making public her marriage to wife Donna
headline: Fired for being gay: church pantry worker sues Kansas City Diocese

standfirst: Nigerian president agrees to meet parents of missing students after talks with Pakistani pupil who survived shooting by Taliban
headline: Malala Yousafzai shows support for Nigerian girls abducted by Boko Haram

standfirst: Dozens of dogs ride the waves on Imperial beach in California as part of an annual surfing competition. First prize for the large dog section went to Hanzo, a boxer owned by Eric Felland of Hollywood, who says of his pet: 'He loves what he does, and people really see that he really loves to surf'
headline: Dogs surf the waves in California – video

standfirst: Surge in number of unaccompanied children crossing border from Central America poses a humanitarian challenge

standfirst: Nikos Maziotis of Revolutionary Struggle captured after gun battle where he, a policeman and two tourists were shot
headline: Capture of Greek terrorist in Athens shootout hailed as police breakthrough

standfirst: Hundreds of thousands of fans in black, red and gold flock to Berlin to see victorious team parade with World Cup trophy
headline: Germany team return to heroes' welcome before Brandenburg Gate

standfirst: A German reporter sings Chancellor Angela Merkel happy birthday at a news conference in Brussels on Thursday. The journalist embarked on the serenade presumably with the expectation that he would be singing in chorus with his colleagues. But no other journalists joined in, prompting Merkel to remark that she should have sung along. Merkel turned 60 on Thursday
headline: Angela Merkel's Happy Birthday fail - video

standfirst: The prime minister says that the parliament has listened to the Australian people and ditched the 'useless, obstructive' carbon tax. The tax, which 'didn't even help the environment' has been removed, he said. Abbott added that the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will be on hand to make sure cost savings are returned to the public
headline: Useless, obstructive carbon tax is gone, says Tony Abbott – video

standfirst: Despite government suspicions, a Hanoi-based hip-hop band is taking a novel approach to broadcasting current affairs bulletins
headline: Here is da news: how rappers hope to switch on Vietnam's young generation

standfirst: Withdrawal of rig welcomed by Hanoi and Washington, but observers still fear escalation of conflict over South China Sea

standfirst: The Liberal Democratic senator David Leyonhjelm says his party is working on a private member's bill to bring marriage equality to Australia, by 'deregulating' it. Leyonhjelm challenged Labor party members to look Senator Penny Wong in the eye and tell her that she does not deserve equal rights. He says he has the support of a number of major-party parliamentarians and says the government should not define people's relationships
headline: Senator prepares equality bill to ‘deregulate’ marriage – video

standfirst: Karyn Parsons, who played Hilary Banks, seeks donations for Sweet Blackberry project, which shares stories of African American achievement

standfirst: A timelapse video filmed on Monday shows the day-one progress of the refloatation of the Costa Concordia. Filmed from 6am until 9am, the video shows the zig-zag motion made by the ferry as it is moved away from the coastline of Giglio. The cruise liner capsized in two years ago, killing 32 people
headline: Costa Concordia timelapse shows day one of salvage - video

standfirst: Former opponents say they will accept legislation as senior bishop asks traditionalists not to defy majority of churchgoers

standfirst: Residents of the eastern Ukrainian city of Luhansk and the town of Maryinka clean up the damage on Saturday after the Ukrainian military shelled parts of the region. The military says the shelling was in retaliation for a rebel missile strike that killed 30 Ukrainian soldiers on Friday

standfirst: Defendants, both 17, convicted over rapes of two women, in seperate incidents, at same disused mill in Mumbai

standfirst: The busiest day of Pamplona's San Fermin festival saw  four people treated for concussion in the traditional chase through the town's streets. A pile-up of runners in the passage leading to the bullring left a number of participants dazed and bruised. Locals and tourists flocked to the event known as 'The Running of the Bulls', made famous by Ernest Hemingway.

standfirst: Merkel celebrates her 60th birthday after eight and a half years as German chancellor. Share your thoughts on her time in power
headline: Angela Merkel turns 60: what has her leadership meant to you?

headline: Liberalism increases as power shifts to the laity in the Church of England

standfirst: Now church can move into 20th century, although perhaps not 21st. A change on gay marriage would be needed to do that

Pro-Russia rebels are blamed as airliner comes down in east Ukraine

standfirst:
Edward Snowden, the NSA whistleblower, talks exclusively to Alan Rusbridger, editor-in-chief of the Guardian, and reporter Ewen MacAskill in Moscow. The 31-year-old former intelligence analyst discusses whether he is a Russian spy, his likely fate if he returns to the US and the relevance of George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-Four in the age of Google

• Read more here and the full interview on Friday
headline: Edward Snowden: 'If I end up in chains in Guantánamo I can live with that' - video interview

standfirst: If increased to six penalty points per offence, the new scheme would mean a driving ban for anyone caught twice in three years

standfirst: The Australian Greens leader, Christine Milne, says it is the height of hypocrisy for the treasurer, Joe Hockey, to talk about a budget emergency on the day that $18bn in revenue is going back to 'the big miners and the big polluters' through the repeal of the carbon tax. The government is 'all about rewarding the big end of town', Milne says

Malaysia Airlines crash in Ukraine stuns country still searching for answers to and wreckage of disappeared flight MH370

• Follow the latest developments on the live blog

standfirst: The operation to refloat the wreck of the cruise ship Costa Concordia gets under way more than two years after it sank with the loss of 32 lives. Technicians begin to pump air into 30 large tanks attached to both sides of the 290-metre ship to expel the water inside and raise the ship. It's the first time a ship this large has ever been salvaged, says Michael Thamm from Costa Cruises
headline: Costa Concordia: wrecked cruise ship to be refloated – video

headline: Russia World Cup 2018: four years of excitement and controversy

headline: Greek shopkeepers stage strike on first day of Sunday trading

standfirst: Geological disturbances caused by 2011 tremors mean active volcano is in a 'critical state', say scientific researchers
headline: Japan earthquake has raised pressure below Mount Fuji, says new study

standfirst: Traffic on Melbourne's Monash Freeway was delayed on Thursday morning after a truck lost its load of apples, leaving a trail of the fruit down the highway. Two lanes were reopened several hours later after the apples and other debris were cleaned up, reportedly after the truck hit a soundwall

standfirst: Traditional faith 'offers no real solutions for the poor' and is a big social problem, says new prelate

standfirst: Iraqi police inspect the scene of a bloody attack at a Baghdad apartment complex where at least 33 people were killed, including 29 women, according to officials. Police officials say the gunmen showed up in four-wheel drive vehicles before storming the buildings. It is thought the men cut through the building's corrugated iron fence to launch the attack

The French national day commemorates the beginning of the French revolution with the storming of the Bastille fortress and prison on 14 July 1789
headline: Eiffel Tower lit up by fireworks for Bastille Day – video

standfirst: In 1966, Harold Wilson assured MPs they would never be bugged. But most in Westminster believe his edict has been quietly circumvented many times over the years. Will new legal challenges shed light on decades of murky practice?
headline: Are spies flouting the 'Wilson doctrine' and bugging MPs?

standfirst: Federico Pizzarotti campaigned to expose corruption but has soon found himself bogged down by bureaucracy

standfirst:
Bathers on a beach in Novosibirsk in Russia's Siberia region are caught by surprise by a hailstorm following a sharp drop in temperature. Mobile phone footage shows people running out of the water to seek cover from the large hailstones, protecting themselves under umbrellas and trees

• Share your pictures of holidays in Siberia
headline: Bathers run for cover as freak hailstorm hits beach in Russia – video

standfirst: At least 10 have died and scores of others injured after a rush-hour underground train derailed in Moscow. Rescue workers carried the injured out of the Park Pobedy station on stretchers and treated them at the scene. The most seriously injured were flown by helicopter to hospital. Investigators believe a power surge may have caused the accident
headline: Moscow rush-hour train derails – video report

standfirst: Russian president says sanctions announced on Wednesday will strain bilateral relations and hurt Russian and US businesses
headline: Vladimir Putin condemns latest US sanctions against Russia

standfirst: Aftermath of a car bomb that exploded in a crowded market in Afghanistan's eastern province of Paktika, killing at least 89 people on Tuesday. There appears to be no government or military target among the dead, apart from the two policemen who tried to stop the bomber. The deadliest previous suicide attack was in southern Kandahar province in 2008, when at least 80 people were killed
headline: Afghanistan car bomb blast aftermath - video

standfirst: In 2003, before the US invasion of Iraq, Luke Harding found the Kurds full of defiance and hope. Returning 11 years later – with Baghdad's hold on power crumbling – he finds a self-confident region transformed by oil money
headline: Revisiting Kurdistan: 'If there is a success story in Iraq, it's here'

standfirst: Bashar al-Assad attends his inauguration ceremony in Damascus where he is sworn in for a third term as president of Syria. Elections took place in the country in June, with many dismissing the result as a sham. Assad takes the oath of office with a hand on the Qur'an, signaling the start of another seven-year term
headline: Syria: Bashar al-Assad sworn in as president - video

standfirst: US pension adviser says move to Switzerland would allow retailer Walgreens to escape the US's far higher corporate tax rate

standfirst: Russian president Vladimir Putin warns on Wednesday that US sanctions will take relations with Russia to a 'dead end' and damage US business interests in his country. The latest US sanctions target two major energy firms, a pair of powerful financial institutions, eight weapons firms and four individuals. They are intended to end the insurgency in eastern Ukraine that is widely believed to be backed by the Kremlin

standfirst: Measures target some of the country's largest energy corporations and banks, and a handful of senior Russian officials

standfirst: Heavy gunfire is heard outside Libya's international airport in Tripoli as Islamist militias attack the rival Zintan group. Anti-aircraft guns and rocket-propelled grenades were used in the skirmish which forced British Airlines and Turkish Airways to cancel their flights. Zintan, which controls the airport, is the main supporter of liberals in parliament who are trying to resist attempts by powerful Islamists hoping to gain power

headline: Iran nuclear talks deadline nears as foreign ministers gather in Vienna

standfirst: US secretary of state says negotiations taking place 'in good faith' though formula for a deal is elusive at the moment
headline: John Kerry acknowledges 'tangible progress' in nuclear talks with Iran

standfirst: US secretary of state John Kerry returned from Vienna to brief President Obama on delicate state of nuclear negotiations with Iranians
headline: Obama indicates extension to Iran nuclear talks as deadline looms

standfirst: Foreign ministers have arrived in Vienna for talks, but before an agreement can be reached several obstacles must be overcome
headline: Five unresolved issues over Iran's nuclear programme

standfirst: Palestinian families in Gaza flee Israeli bombardments, amid warnings of more air strikes. At the Israeli border tanks fire at targets inside Gaza, while Israeli military fired from the air on Monday. Thousands of people left their homes after Israel warned it would intensify its fire. One woman who was sheltering in a school run by the UN says there is no water and her children are sleeping on classroom floors
headline: Gaza families flee Israeli bombardment - video

standfirst: Tourists in Eliat watch security personnel survey the scene after three rockets hit the Israeli holiday resort on Tuesday. Several people were injured and cars and buildings were damaged. A local police officer says people should stay inside and take cover when they hear sirens. The rockets are believed to have been fired from Egypt's Sinai region by those hostile to a peace deal being brokered by Egypt
headline: Israeli holiday resort Eilat targeted by rockets – video

standfirst: Gaza City was rocked by a series of large blasts in the early hours of Sunday morning. The explosions came as violence escalated between Israel and Hamas with more exchanges of rocket fire from Gaza and missiles from Israel. On the same night, an Israeli warplane flattened the home of Gaza police chief Taysir al-Batsh and damaged a nearby mosque as evening prayers ended
headline: Gaza City rocked by explosions overnight - video

standfirst: The Israeli prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, accuses Hamas of using civilians to hide their missiles while trying to kill as many Israelis as possible. Speaking in Tel Aviv to a US-based TV network he says the current Israeli offensive is targeting the Palestinian militants who are firing rockets
headline: Binyamin Netanyahu accuses Hamas of trying to kill as many Israelis as possible – video

standfirst: International pressure to curb civilian casualties is mounting as a charitable centre in Gaza is destroyed in an Israeli attack targeting a suspected militant
headline: Disabled Palestinians unable to escape Israeli air strike

standfirst: Middle East envoy Tony Blair says he welcomes the Egyptian ceasefire plan as an opportunity to bring permanent security to the region. At a joint news conference in Jerusalem with Israeli's president Shimon Peres, Blair says the ceasefire proposal could bring a long-term solution to Israel and Gaza
headline: Tony Blair meets Israeli president and hails Egypt's ceasefire plan – video

standfirst: Synagogue under police guard after youths tried to storm building, trapping those inside, following march in capital
headline: Hollande urges Middle East diplomacy after pro-Palestinian protest in Paris

standfirst: As in the field, Israel deploys superior strength and resources as both sides attack each other on Twitter, Facebook and YouTube
headline: Israel and Hamas clash on social media

standfirst: The Guardian’s picture editors bring you a selection of the best photographs from around the world including the supermoon, Bastille Day, Pamplona, and a giant ex-parrot
headline: Photo highlights of the day

standfirst: Campaigners against sexual violence welcome long prison terms, as seven given life and two 20-year sentences
headline: Egypt jails nine men convicted of sexual assault during Sisi inauguration rally

standfirst:
In June, Jeremiah Heaton planted a flag in small region between Egypt and Sudan in a bid to make his daughter a princess. Now he hopes it will improve global food security

• Bim Adewunmi: Are white people still allowed to do this?
headline: American plans to use 'his' piece of Africa for advancement of science

standfirst: Foreign minister says Tehran willing to pause development for seven years, as nuclear talks in Vienna near conclusion
headline: Iran makes offer over uranium enrichment programme

standfirst: Activists claim fashion mogul Peter Nygard's proposed development risks environmental damage to beaches
headline: Sean Connery joins Bahamas campaign to stop billionaire developing mansion

standfirst: Israel has launched more than 1,300 air strikes since its offensive began, and Palestinian militants have launched more than 800 rockets at Israel, the Israeli military has said. Gaza's health ministry said 166 Palestinians had been killed. There have been no Israeli fatalities
headline: Hamas/Israel conflict continues – in pictures

standfirst: Israeli troops are seen positioned near the Gaza border on Wednesday morning, as Israel resumed its air strikes in Gaza a day after an Egyptian-proposed ceasefire deal, leaving at least three Palestinians dead. The Israeli military say that since the ceasefire deal was to have gone into effect, Hamas had fired 123 rockets at Israel, one killing a civilian - the first Israeli fatality in the fighting
headline: Israeli air strikes in Gaza after ceasfire collapse - video

standfirst: A Palestinian group says 869 homes been ruined or damaged in Israeli attacks. In Shati, a crowd witnesses one such strike
headline: A knock on the roof, then another Gaza home destroyed by Israeli missile

standfirst: Israel agreed to Egypt-brokered truce but resumes bombing after Palestinian group says its demands were not met
headline: Israel bombards Gaza after Hamas rejects proposals and resumes rocket attacks

standfirst: Contrast with Gaza destruction is striking but Tel Aviv is not always this peaceful, with rockets a continuing threat
headline: In bustling Tel Aviv, Israelis feel strain of war

standfirst: Raid is first time Israeli forces have set foot in Gaza during current conflict, and leaflets warn of large-scale bombing
headline: Israeli commandos raid Gaza beach as deadly air assault continues

standfirst: Palestinian mosque hit and two people at charity for disabled reported to be among latest victims of Operation Protective Edge
headline: Israel continues Gaza bombardment, pushing death toll past 120

standfirst: Hamas under pressure to halt rocket attacks after rejecting Cairo-brokered peace deal, saying it had not been consulted
headline: Israel accepts Egypt ceasefire plan to end Gaza fighting

standfirst: Hamas calls for international action over an Israeli air strike on Gaza beach that left four children dead and another seriously injured. Spokesman Sami Abu Zuhri calls on Ban Ki-moon and the United Nations to act on what he describes as Israeli war crimes. Gaza health officials say 207 Palestinians, most of them civilians, have died in the Israeli offensive since 8 July
headline: Gaza: Israeli strike kills four children on beach - video

  • Violence resumes after five-hour truce
  • UNRWA condemns hiding of rockets in a school

headline: Israeli military begins ground offensive in Gaza – live updates

standfirst: First Israeli killed in conflict by one of 50 rockets fired from Gaza during halt in Israeli bombardment
headline: Israel resumes air strikes after Hamas ceasefire rejection kills civilian

  • Four boys killed on beach spurs anger in Gaza

headline: Israeli killed by mortar shell near Gaza as Palestinian death toll nears 200

standfirst:
Israel to hit Beit Lahia area, home to at least 100,000 people, targeting what it says are rocket-launching sites

Read more: Stephen Hawking's boycott hits Israel where it hurts
headline: Thousands flee Gaza homes after Israeli warning of large-scale bombing

standfirst: Neighbourhood next to Tel Aviv's missile defence system has no bomb shelters
headline: No safe haven for those living near Israel's Iron Dome

standfirst: Netanyahu's security cabinet discusses limited ground operation in Gaza as more Palestinians killed in overnight attacks
headline: Israeli air strikes target Hamas leaders as ceasefire fails

standfirst: There is a deafening explosion, then a second. Four children are dead. Four survivors reach the safety of our hotel
headline: Witness to a shelling: first-hand account of deadly strike on Gaza port

standfirst: This new, stupid conflict will ultimately change nothing and will end like the others – in an edgy truce
headline: Gaza war is futile. Neither side can win

standfirst: Israel and Hamas exchange fire on the Israel-Gaza border on Thursday night as the Israeli prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu instructs the military to begin a ground offensive in Gaza. Israel's decision to move troops into Gaza follows clashes earlier in the day as a temporary humanitarian ceasefire ended
headline: Israel exchanges fire with Hamas as its troops begin a ground offensive in Gaza - video

standfirst: Negotiations between Israel and Hamas reach 'critical 24 hours' after Cairo talks during brief humanitarian ceasefire
headline: Israel seeks ceasefire that will restore authority to Abbas, says official

standfirst: Unmanned aircraft is said to have been downed using Patriot missile near city of Ashdod on southern coast
headline: Israel says it has shot down drone launched from Gaza

standfirst: Egypt says it has not been involved in any talks since collapse of proposed ceasefire and resumption of Israeli air strikes
headline: Hamas tells Egypt it rejects Gaza ceasefire

standfirst: Israeli prime minister set to authorise call-up of more reserve soldiers, as death toll from Israel's bombing passes 200 in Gaza
headline: Binyamin Netanyahu: Hamas has 'shut the door' to diplomatic solutions

standfirst: Twenty seven Brits and their dependents leave region via humanitarian corridor negotiated with Israel
headline: Brits among foreigners evacuated from Gaza as death toll climbs

standfirst: Security cabinet agrees to plan calling for Israel not to invade Gaza and for Palestinian militants to stop firing rockets
headline: Israel approves Egyptian proposal for Gaza ceasefire with Hamas

standfirst: Arab League and EU back Kerry's calls for return to 2012 truce as Hague says any deal must improve conditions in Gaza
headline: Immediate Gaza ceasefire unlikely as Israel tries to hurt but not kill Hamas

standfirst: Three mortars fired into Israel during five-hour 'humanitarian pause' in hostilities brokered by UN
headline: Mortars fired from Gaza during ceasefire between Israel and Hamas

standfirst: Israeli prime minister fires deputy defence minister Danny Danon for saying Hamas humiliated Israel by setting peace conditions
headline: Netanyahu criticised by cabinet members over Gaza crisis

standfirst: As the number of Palestinians killed since Tuesday exceeds 120, Israel says it will continue its offensive in Gaza until Hamas militants are defeated. At least two disabled women were killed in Israeli shelling of a rehabilitation facility. The women are among 16 Palestinians reported to have died in Israeli air strikes early on Saturday morning
headline: Israel vows to continue bombarding Gaza as number of dead rises - video

standfirst: Border crossing is a lifeline for Palestinians, but Egypt does not want to gift Hamas something that would increase its popularity
headline: Reopening of Rafah crossing top priority for Hamas in ceasefire talks

standfirst: Gaza's streets fill with people as businesses open their doors for the first time in eight days and locals reflect on the conflict
headline: 'I want peace. I'm exhausted by war': Gazans speak out amid brief lull

standfirst: A White House spokesman says the US is 'concerned' about loss of both Palestinian and Israeli life in recent violence between Hamas and Israel. Josh Earnest claims Hamas should accept a ceasefire deal and stop firing rockets aimed at Israeli civilians. Gaza says 207 Palestinians have been killed in the violence which began on 8 July; one Israeli has been killed by rocket fire from Hamas
headline: White House: Gaza situation 'not beneficial to either side' - video

standfirst: Hamas unable to persuade Israel and Egypt to release recently captured prisoners and to ease blockade
headline: Israel's attack on Gaza follows talks in which no one was ready to back down
